column4: if i do that it outputs nothing and typing ./test gives no such file or directory
type which <program> , make sure it's in your path
if you just added that path in that terminal, open another
in ~/.bashrc , add the line  PATH=/home/D/dsss/bin:$PATH
and it's possible that your program is looking for support files or something, and doesn't look in the executable's directory like it should
tried that interesting thing i made script, then chmod u+x it if i type test (name of script) it doesn't print anything but ./test does
try cd ~ , then run it. Make sure you're not in the same dir. But it seems that there is something wrong with your path yet
it doesn't say command not found though so i think the path part is working
yes I would agree ~ doesn't have test in it, that's why ./test didn't work (./ means current directory)
so make a short script that does cd to the right directory, then runs the program with ./ see if that works
so why even when i'm in the same folder would the script not output anything when run using 'test' but would when using './test' ???
off the top of my head? Not sure :)
that's a sure sign something is wrong with the path
don't do that :)
cd ~ , then try the foobar , as bascule pointed out the current directory is not on the path
paste the output of $PATH
echo $PATH that is
now  the output of pwd while you are in your home
and finally the output of pwd when you are in the dsss/bin dir
aha!   it should be /home/matthew/D/dss/bin  in your path
was assuming your home dir was named D
